4.text: In this episode, I meet National Gallery Curator Betsy Wieseman

8.text: to discuss the topsy-turvy majesty of the Drunken Silenus supported by Satyrs.

18.text: Betsy, I really adore this picture. >> As do I.

22.text: I think it's phenomenal, and I guess before we get stuck into what it represents

26.text: and so on, there is a question mark about who actually painted it.

30.text: Because to the layman, it looks like a Rubens—17th century Rubens.

35.text: But that's probably not quite what we're looking at.

38.text: Right. It is definitely Rubensean in that sense that we understand it

43.text: being just full of life, full of flesh, full of joie de vivre.

48.text: But Rubens, as we know, operated an enormous workshop

51.text: that enabled him to meet all the commissions that he received.

54.text: And one of the confusing things is that it wasn't just a case of this artist

61.text: or that artist. It was this artist and perhaps that artist and maybe this person did something as well.

68.text: So we think van Dyck might have been responsible for the figures possibly.

72.text: Maybe Rubens had a few brush strokes in there.

75.text: And the still life elements of these wonderful juicy grapes in the foreground

80.text: and the fruits dangling from the tree we think might have been done by another artist,

85.text: Frans Snyders. >> You look at this and you see this wonderfully in places

90.text: blurred, inebriated painted scene in which clearly this is some sort of party

96.text: that's gone very, very well. And it's dominated by the fleshy presence

102.text: of this naked old bloke in the middle. Who is he?

107.text: It's Silenus, who was the friend and companion of Bacchus,

112.text: the god of wine. And from some things that I've read,

116.text: I think taught Bacchus how to drink. So Silenus really knew how to enjoy himself.

122.text: Here we have someone who is very full of life, very full of wine,

127.text: and just showing the pleasures of abundance. And that flesh of his torso,

133.text: you can imagine it. It's so beautifully rendered, you feel it might be slightly sweaty.

139.text: It's loose. It's almost overflowing onto the arm of the satyr who's supporting him.

146.text: It's wobbling before our eyes. Isn't it? >> Absolutely.

148.text: And I love this sort of blurred execution of the figures gives you that sense of wobbling flesh

154.text: that you can't quite focus on, or perhaps it's because you've had too many glasses of wine

159.text: that you can't quite focus on these figures.

162.text: But this is—I have to say this is a happy drunk.

164.text: This is not something that's going to end badly.

168.text: He's just going to fall into bed laughing at the end of this, I think.

173.text: Do we know much—I mean—clearly some of the followers

176.text: just augment and enhance that atmosphere of inebriation.

180.text: I think he just had a band of satyrs and bacchants that accompanied him.

185.text: There's a beautiful young blond and then an older bacchant

189.text: who's clearly been around the block a few times.

192.text: You know, how significant is it that you can't really imagine—

197.text: at least I can't think of high Renaissance painters who want to examine

201.text: with such interest and observation that full fleshy torso of an old man.

207.text: No, and I think van Dyck or Rubens or whoever painted this wonderful thing,

212.text: he's very much a human and I think something that the viewer can relate to

219.text: a little more directly. And I think that is one of the very important qualities

225.text: of the Baroque versus the Renaissance.
